body: Pinging @juhasch

Same same, but different.

With your changes the size doesn't change anymore. But there still is
`@-moz-document url-prefix(){.CodeMirror-scroll{overflow-x:hidden}}.CodeMirror-lines{padding:.4em}`
 in `style.min.css` which cuts away most of the last line in the codecell, if there is a scroll bar.
If I remove this line, it cuts away part of the cell output.

Sounds like cache problems, that line should be removed (see diff): https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/5446/files#diff-6ad1b5e12450c5b9024e7e7770aa35b9L85
Line 85
Yes, I missed replacing `style.min.css`. Now it looks good! Great!

> Now it looks good! Great!

Yay!  That's great news.  I had talked to @ellisonbg about removing the flexible box model in the cell layout earlier.  He probably knows about the possible repercussions of doing this, so he should probably review it.  Also it's probably a good idea to not try to squeeze this in to 2.0, since this area of the code base has proven to be fragile :warning:
I understand that, Firefox seems to be a little odd in this respect. For now, I will keep your updated CSS files in my local static directory. Hope it will be fixed in 2.1, though.
~~WIP: Making FF and Chrome look the same.~~
FF and Chrome agree now
@jdfreder do you have time to rebase this this week?
I do, I'll go ahead and do that now.
Internet connect was spotty, just got back to the hotel and pushed the rebase.

The input prompt div no longer matches the height of the input area next to it. I noticed this because my custom CSS sets the background of the prompt area, which now looks a bit funky.

I also notice that the output area is still a flexbox. Can you describe a bit more where/when flexbox is still used, and where it's been removed?

> I also notice that the output area is still a flexbox. Can you describe a bit more where/when flexbox is still used, and where it's been removed?

The users will still be able to use the flexible box model in their widget/interact layouts.  My thought was the users may, knowing how the flexible box model works with the widgets, also use it for their HTML output.  Although, even without the flexible box model defined at this level, they could always dump their output into a containing div with the flexible box model enabled.  My general intent was to leave the notebook untouched where I could, and only remove the flexible box model where it proved to be problematic.

> The input prompt div no longer matches the height of the input area next to it. I noticed this because my custom CSS sets the background of the prompt area, which now looks a bit funky.

Okay, I just looked into this some more.  It seems that floating the prompt DIV prevents it from respecting the parent's height (event when it is set to 100%).

![divheights](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2946702/2943d06a-d9ee-11e3-87b3-27d45ed1eadc.png)

What I can do, instead of floating the div, is explicitly set the parent's positioning to relative and then set the prompt's positioning to absolute.  Although the 100% height actually makes the element larger than the codemirror editor (as seen below), I could probably using padding or margins to correct this.  Is this preferred?

![divheights_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2946752/ba3d2026-d9ee-11e3-80b4-4e5c4e3bd8db.png)

- It might help to change the box-sizing CSS attribute.
- If we mess with the positioning like this, we should absolutely get the
  prompt area to have the right size/margin/padding.

> wrote:

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

> - It might help to change the box-sizing CSS attribute.

The std box model attributes don't seem to do anything since the div is floated.

Ok, I've pushed a solution, results shown below:

![divheights_3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2948213/299c6b24-d9ff-11e3-8d54-9b20b7dae8c1.png)
That's still not quite right - you have an extra pixel of height on the bottom.

> you have an extra pixel of height on the bottom.

Damn, hopefully that's not a result of the cell border or something.  _looking_

> you have an extra pixel of height on the bottom.

Last commits should fix this, see screenshot below:

![divheights_4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2948970/01fc55fc-da09-11e3-90b3-2eda3b7632e3.png)

It really seems like flexbox is the right tool for the job here. Is there perhaps another way to deal with the problems this is meant to address? It seems like removing flexbox might not actually be the way to do it.

> Is there perhaps another way to deal with the problems this is meant to address?

I had a lot of trouble finding out how to handle CodeMirror correctly within a flexbox, but that doesn't mean there isn't a 'right' way to do it.  It could just be something I missed.  I can either work on this until it works for our edge cases, or change gears and try to get the scrollbars/CodeMirror stuff to work correctly with the flexible model.  Thoughts?  Did you want to look at it?
I'm honestly not sure. Maybe I will look into getting flexbox to work correctly, and you can keep trying to get non-flexbox to work? Nothing seems ideal, and some work is bound to be wasted.

It is entirely possible that we need to keep with flexbox...sorry this
stuff is so horrible though...

On Mon, May 12, 2014 at 12:20 PM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:

> I'm honestly not sure. Maybe I will look into getting flexbox to work
> correctly, and you can keep trying to get non-flexbox to work? Nothing
> seems ideal, and some work is bound to be wasted.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/5446#issuecomment-42875809
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

I'm curious---have you tried moving to CodeMirror 4.x?  IIRC, that was a significant rewrite, and may change the story here.  If not, Marijn might be interested in hearing about the problems.  (I don't know what the problems are, though...)

Doh!  I forgot to apply similar logic to the output stuff.  I think I've made the necessary fixes, see the latest commits (and the following screenshots).  I'm not quite sure what I'm supposed to do with the output scroll handler on small screens...

![divheights_5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2949389/5458f1ac-da0e-11e3-8c07-30218a0560f3.png)

![divheights_6](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3292874/2949408/7e561a84-da0e-11e3-9465-b12abde99298.png)

> have you tried moving to CodeMirror 4.x?

I haven't tried that yet, but you're right, we should.  We will have to make the switch sometimes anyways, might as well check now. :)
I don't see the latest commit for this PR on GH (maybe it's glitching) - 6f33e9e029db9d547c4
57f615822550fc81e8 seems to be missing too...
This seems to work will all of the edge cases now (the ones I know about).  Still not sure what the desired behavior is for the output scroll handler on small screens.
Closing in favor of #5843 and the fact that 1/2 of this is a Chrome bug, fixed in later releases (the vertical area not downsizing).
